sections.introduction:
Many computationally hard graph problems can be solved efficiently if we place constraints on the input.
Instead of solving individual problems in an ad hoc way we may try to decompose the vertex set of the input graph into large sets of “similarly behaving” vertices and to exploit this decomposition for an algorithmic speed up that works for many problems simultaneously. This requires some notion of an “optimal” vertex decomposition, which depends on the type of vertex decomposition used and which may relate to the minimum number of sets or the maximum size of a set in a vertex decomposition. An optimal vertex decomposition gives us the “width” of the graph. A graph class has bounded width if every graph in the class has width at most some constant c𝑐c. Boundedness of width is often the underlying reason why a graph-class-specific algorithm runs efficiently: in this case, the proof that the algorithm is efficient for some special graph class reduces to a proof showing that the width of the class is bounded by some constant. We will give examples, but also refer to the
surveys 4    
for further details and examples. Width parameters differ in strength. A width parameter p𝑝p dominates a width parameter q𝑞q if there is a function f𝑓f such that p​(G)𝑝𝐺p(G) is at most f​(q​(G))𝑓𝑞𝐺f(q(G)) for every graph G𝐺G. If p𝑝p dominates q𝑞q but q𝑞q does not dominate p𝑝p, then we say that p𝑝p is more powerful than q𝑞q. If both p𝑝p and q𝑞q dominate each other, then p𝑝p and q𝑞q are equivalent.
If neither p𝑝p is more powerful than q𝑞q nor q𝑞q is more powerful than p𝑝p, then p𝑝p and q𝑞q are incomparable.
If p𝑝p is more powerful than q𝑞q, then
the class of graphs for which p𝑝p is bounded is larger than the class of graphs for which q𝑞q is bounded and so efficient algorithms for bounded p𝑝p have greater applicability with respect to the graphs under consideration.
The trade-off is that fewer problems exhibit an efficient algorithm for the parameter p𝑝p, compared to the parameter q𝑞q. This notion of powerfulness leads to a large hierarchy of width parameters, in which new width parameters continue to be defined,
for example, graph functionality  in 2019 and twin-width  in 2020.
The well-known parameters boolean-width, clique-width, module-width and rank-width are equivalent to each other 6 0 4. They are more powerful than the equivalent parameters branch-width and treewidth  5  but less powerful than mim-width , which is less powerful than sim-width . To give another example, thinness is more powerful than path-width , but less powerful than mim-width and incomparable to clique-width or treewidth . For each group of equivalent width parameters, a growing set of NP-complete problems is known to be tractable on graph classes of bounded width. Proving the latter for some graph class often immediately tells us that many problems are tractable for that class without the need for constructing algorithms for each problem.
However, there are still large families of graph classes, and many width parameters, for which it is not known whether the class has bounded width. Our Focus.
We consider the relatively new width parameter mim-width, which we define below.
Recently, we showed in 3 4 that boundedness of mim-width is the underlying reason why
some specific hereditary graph classes, characterized by two forbidden induced subgraphs,
admit polynomial-time algorithms for a range of problems including k𝑘k-Colouring and its generalization List k𝑘k-Colouring (the algorithms are
given in   ).
Here we prove that the same holds for certain superclasses of convex graphs known in the literature.
Essentially all the known polynomial-time algorithms for such classes are obtained by reducing to the class of convex graphs. We show that our new approach
via mim-width simplifies the analysis, unifies the sporadic approaches
and explains the reductions to convex graphs. Mim-width.

A bipartite graph G=(A,B,E)𝐺𝐴𝐵𝐸G=(A,B,E) is convex if there exists a path P𝑃P with V​(P)=A𝑉𝑃𝐴V(P)=A such that the neighbours in A𝐴A of each b∈B𝑏𝐵b\in B induce a connected subpath of P𝑃P. Convex graphs generalize bipartite permutation graphs
(see, e.g., 0)
and form a well-studied graph class.
They were introduced in the sixties, by Glover , to solve a special type of matching problem arising in some industrial application. Another early paper solving matching problems on convex graphs is by Lipski and Preparata . Belmonte and Vatshelle  proved that the mim-width of convex graphs is bounded and quickly computable.
We consider superclasses of convex graphs and research to what extent mim-width can play a role in obtaining polynomial-time algorithms for problems on these classes. Let ℋℋ{\cal H} be a family of graphs.

Hence, the result of  for convex graphs cannot be generalized to chordal bipartite graphs. We determine the mim-width of the other classes in Figure 2 but first discuss known algorithmic results for these classes. Known Results.
Belmonte and Vatshelle  and Bui-Xuan et al. 7 proved that so-called Locally Checkable Vertex Subset and Vertex Partitioning (LC-VSVP) problems, first defined in 8,
are polynomial-time solvable on graph classes whose mim-width is bounded and quickly computable.
This result was extended by Bergougnoux and Kanté [ref]3 to variants of such problems with additional constraints on connectivity or acyclicity.
Each of the problems mentioned below is a special case of a Locally Checkable Vertex Subset (LCVS) problem
possibly with one of the two extra constraints.
We refer to the listed papers for the definitions of the problems, as we do not need them here. Panda et al. 2 proved that Induced Matching is polynomial-time solvable for
circular convex and triad convex graphs, but NP-complete for star convex and comb convex graphs. Pandey and Panda 3 proved that Dominating Set is polynomial-time solvable for circular convex, triad convex and
(1,Δ)1Δ(1,\Delta)-tree convex graphs for every Δ≥1Δ1\Delta\geq 1. Liu et al.  proved that Connected Dominating Set is polynomial-time solvable for circular convex and triad convex graphs. Chen et al. 8 showed that Dominating Set, Connected Dominating Set
and Total Dominating Set are
NP-complete for star convex and comb convex graphs. Lu et al.  proved that Independent Dominating Set is polynomial-time solvable for circular convex and triad convex graphs. The latter result was previously shown in 7 using a dynamic programming approach instead of a reduction to convex graphs . Song et al. 7 showed in fact a stronger result, namely that Independent Dominating Set
is polynomial-time solvable for (t,Δ)𝑡Δ(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs for every t≥1𝑡1t\geq 1 and Δ≥3Δ3\Delta\geq 3. They also showed that Independent Dominating Set is NP-complete for star convex and comb convex graphs 7. Hence, they obtained a dichotomy: Independent Dominating Set is polynomial-time solvable for (t,Δ)𝑡Δ(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs for every t≥1𝑡1t\geq 1 and Δ≥3Δ3\Delta\geq 3 but NP-complete for (∞,3)3(\infty,3)-tree convex graphs and (1,∞)1(1,\infty)-tree convex graphs. The same dichotomy (explicitly formulated in 1)
holds for Feedback Vertex Set and is obtained similarly. Namely, Jiang et al.  proved that this problem is polynomial-time solvable for triad convex graphs and mentioned that their algorithm can be generalized to (t,Δ)𝑡Δ(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs for every t≥1𝑡1t\geq 1 and Δ≥3Δ3\Delta\geq 3.
Jiang et al.  proved that Feedback Vertex Set is NP-complete for star convex and comb convex graphs.
In addition, Liu et al.  proved that Feedback Vertex Set is polynomial-time solvable for circular convex graphs, whereas Jiang et al.  proved that the Weighted Feedback Vertex Set problem is polynomial-time solvable for triad convex graphs. It turns out that the above problems are polynomial-time solvable on circular convex graphs and subclasses of (t,Δ)𝑡Δ(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs, but NP-complete for star convex graphs and comb convex graphs.
In contrast, Panda and Chaudhary 1 proved that Dominating Induced Matching is not only polynomial-time solvable on circular convex and triad convex graphs, but also on star convex graphs.
Nevertheless, we notice a common pattern: many dominating set, induced matching and graph transversal type of problems are polynomial-time solvable for (t,Δ)𝑡Δ(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs, for every t≥1𝑡1t\geq 1 and Δ≥3Δ3\Delta\geq 3, and NP-complete for comb convex graphs, and thus for (∞,3)3(\infty,3)-tree convex graphs, and star convex graphs, or equivalently, (1,∞)1(1,\infty)-tree convex graphs. Moreover, essentially all the polynomial-time algorithms reduce the input to a convex graph. Our Results.
We simplify the analysis, unify the above approaches and explain the reductions to convex graphs, using mim-width. We prove three results that, together with the fact that chordal bipartite graphs have unbounded mim-width 2, explain the dotted line in Figure 2. The first two results generalize the result of  for convex graphs. The third result gives two new reasons why tree convex graphs (that is, (∞,∞)(\infty,\infty)-tree convex graphs) have unbounded mim-width. The mim-width of the class of circular convex graphs is bounded and quickly computable. For every t,Δ∈ℕ𝑡Δℕt,\Delta\in\mathbb{N} with t≥1𝑡1t\geq 1 and Δ≥3Δ3\Delta\geq 3,
the mim-width of the class of (t,Δ)𝑡Δ(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs is bounded and quickly computable. The class of star convex graphs and the class of comb convex graphs have unbounded mim-width. Hence, we obtain a structural dichotomy (recall that star convex graphs are the (1,∞)1(1,\infty)-tree convex graphs and that
comb convex graphs are (∞,3)3(\infty,3)-tree convex): Let t,Δ∈ℕ∪{∞}𝑡Δℕt,\Delta\in\mathbb{N}\cup\{\infty\} with t≥1𝑡1t\geq 1 and Δ≥3Δ3\Delta\geq 3.
The class of (t,Δ)𝑡Δ(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs has bounded mim-width if and only if {t,Δ}∩{∞}=∅𝑡Δ\{t,\Delta\}\cap\{\infty\}=\varnothing. Algorithmic Consequences.
As discussed, the following six problems were shown to be 𝖭𝖯𝖭𝖯\mathsf{NP}-complete for star convex and comb convex graphs, and thus for (1,∞)1(1,\infty)-tree convex graphs and (∞,3)3(\infty,3)-tree convex graphs:
Feedback Vertex Set [ref]3 ;
Dominating Set, Connected Dominating Set, Total Dominating Set 8;
Independent Dominating Set 7;
Induced Matching 2.
These problems are examples of LCVS problems,
possibly with connectivity or acyclicity constraints. Hence, they are polynomial-time solvable for every graph class whose mim-width is bounded and quickly
computable  [ref]3 7.
Recall that the same holds for Weighted Feedback Vertex Set  and (Weighted) Subset Feedback Vertex Set ; these three problems generalize Feedback Vertex Set and are thus NP-complete for
star convex graphs and comb convex graphs.
Combining these results with Corollary 1 yields the following complexity dichotomy. Let t,Δ∈ℕ∪{∞}𝑡Δℕt,\Delta\in\mathbb{N}\cup\{\infty\} with

if {t,Δ}∩{∞}=∅𝑡Δ\{t,\Delta\}\cap\{\infty\}=\varnothing, and NP-complete otherwise. Outline.
We prove Theorems 1.1–1.3 in Sections 2–4, respectively, by showing additional structural results.
First, in Section 2, we prove Theorem 1.1 by showing a similar but stronger result for linear mim-width of circular convex graphs.
Next, in Section 3, we prove a stronger version of Theorem 1.2; namely we prove the result for thinness, a relatively recent graph width parameter introduced in .
This replaces the more direct proof given in .
Finally, in Section 4, we prove that Theorem 1.3 follows from a stronger result as well: we prove that star convex graphs and comb convex graphs have unbounded sim-width. Recall that the latter width parameter is more powerful than mim-width . The above additional results naturally beg the question for a more refined analysis on width parameters for generalized convex classes.
We perform this analysis in Section 5. There, we consider a hierarchy of width parameters, which include mim-width and thinness. We determine exactly which of the generalized convex classes considered in the previous sections have bounded width for each of these parameters.
We are not yet aware of any new algorithmic results arising from this analysis,
but in Section 7 we give some directions for future research, after proving Theorem 1.4 in Section 6. Preliminaries.

A graph is r𝑟r-partite, for r≥2𝑟2r\geq 2, if its vertex set admits a partition into r𝑟r classes such that every edge has its endpoints in different classes. A 222-partite graph is also called bipartite. A graph G𝐺G is a support for a hypergraph H=(V,𝒮)𝐻𝑉𝒮H=(V,\mathcal{S}) if the vertices of G𝐺G correspond to the vertices of H𝐻H and, for each hyperedge S∈𝒮𝑆𝒮S\in\mathcal{S}, the subgraph of G𝐺G induced by S𝑆S is connected.
When a bipartite graph G=(A,B,E)𝐺𝐴𝐵𝐸G=(A,B,E) is viewed as a hypergraph H=(A,{N​(b):b∈B})𝐻𝐴conditional-set𝑁𝑏𝑏𝐵H=(A,\{N(b):b\in B\}), then a support T𝑇T for H𝐻H with T∈ℋ𝑇ℋT\in\mathcal{H} is a witness that G𝐺G is ℋℋ\mathcal{H}-convex.
